revision.text:
'''Turn Your Back on Bush''' was a form of [[protest]] in the United States to express dissatisfaction with former President [[George W. Bush]]. The first known protest took place on June 14, 2002 in [[Columbus, Ohio]] where President Bush delivered a commencement address to the graduating class of [[Ohio State University]] and an audience of over 50,000 people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2002/06/20020614-1.html |title=full text |publisher=Georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov |date=2002-06-14 |accessdate=2009-07-17}}</ref> ==Background== A group identified as a coalition of concerned students, graduates, alumni, faculty, staff, guests, and community members on the website turnyourbackonbush.com instructed participants to "stand up silently and turn your back while Bush gives his commencement address." The students and guests at the event were publicly threatened by University administration if they participated in protest.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hart |first=Peter |url=http://www.fair.org/index.php?page=2644 |title=Reporter Hears "Adulation" for Bush, Not Threats Against Protesters |publisher=Fair.org |date= |accessdate=2009-07-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.progressive.org/mag_mcohiostate |title=Anti-Bush Protesters Silenced at Ohio State Graduation | The Progressive Magazine since 1909 |publisher=Progressive.org |date= |accessdate=2009-07-17}}</ref>
The phrase was first coined by Hillary Tinapple, one of the organizers of the Ohio State University commencement protest and member of the 2002 graduating class. Since the controversial second election of Bush, Turn Your Back on Bush has become a grassroots organization,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.turnyourbackonbush.org |title=Turn Your Back on Bush |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2009-07-17}}</ref> co-founded by Jet Heiko.<ref>{{cite web|last=Blanding |first=Michael |url=http://www.alternet.org/story/21051 |title=Taking It To The Streets |publisher=AlterNet |date=2005-01-21 |accessdate=2009-07-17}}</ref>
On January 20, 2005, a Turn Your Back on Bush demonstration took place at the President's second Inaugural parade. The organization's website states that over 5,000 people from around the country participated in this protest by lining the parade route with their backs turned while the motorcade passed by. This was among many counter-inauguration protests that took place in [[Washington, D.C.]] and around the United States on that same day (see [[January 20, 2005 counter-inaugural protest]]).<ref>[http://www.concordmonitor.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20050121/REPOSITORY/501210372/1037/NEWS04 Concord Monitor - Protesters make presence felt<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Media coverage of the Turn Your Back on Bush inaugural protest appeared in several mainstream publications and was used in a segment of NBC's comedy television show ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''.
